64678 S1872-2067(25)64678-X 10.1016/S1872-2067(25)64678-X Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, the Chinese Academy of Sciences Fig. 1 (a) Schematic illustration for the preparation of MH-ZSM-5. TEM images of parent ZSM-5 (b), HH-ZSM-5 (c) and MH-ZSM-5 (d) samples. (e,f) Aberration-corrected HAADF-STEM images (the generated mesopores are highlighted by yellow circles). iDPC-STEM image (the Ga species are highlighted by red circles) (g) and corresponding EDX elemental mappings (h–j) of Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.41. STEM-HAADF images with EDS line scanning profiles of Ga/H-ZSM-5 (k), Ga/HH-ZSM-5 (l) and Ga/MH-ZSM-5 (m) samples. Fig. 2 Propane conversion, product selectivity and aromatic product distribution with the time-on-stream (TOS) over Ga/H-ZSM-5 (a,b), Ga/HH-ZSM-5 (c,d) and Ga/MH-ZSM-5 (e,f) sample. Reaction conditions: 540 °C, 1 atm, WHSVpropane = 1.4 h–1 (N2/C3H8 = 2.5 (vol/vol)). Fig. 3 Propane conversions, aromatics selectivities and yields (a), and aromatic product distributions (b) obtained on MH-ZSM-5 and Ga-MH-ZSM-5-x samples (reaction conditions: T = 540 °C, 1 atm, WHSVpropane = 0.96 h–1 and N2/C3H8 = 2.5 (vol/vol)). Propane conversion, product selectivity (c), and aromatic products distribution (d) with TOS obtained on the Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.41 (reaction conditions: T = 580 °C, 1 atm, WHSVpropane = 1.1 h–1 and N2/C3H8 = 2.5 (vol/vol)). (e) Aromatics and BTX yields obtained on our synthesized and reported catalysts. (f) TONs (green and pink columns represent the catalytic results of various reported Ga and Zn catalysts respectively). Data in this work were obtained from Fig. S14(c) (540 °C and TOS of 100 h) and Fig. S10 (580 °C and TOS of 50 h). TON is the accumulated amount (moles) of generated aromatics per mole of Ga or Zn species, as obtained from the equation of TON = , where F C3H8 is propane carbon molar flow rate; Y aro,t is instantaneous aromatics carbon molar yield at the time on stream of t; t is reaction time, and nM is the moles of Ga or Zn species of catalysts. Fig. 4 (a) Normalized Ga K-edge XANES spectra collected at ambient temperature of Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.082 (1), Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.13 (2), Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.30 (3), Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.47 (4), Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.70 (5), Ga-MH-ZSM-5-1.10 (6), Ga-MH-ZSM-5-1.62 (7) and β-Ga2O3 in the first-coordination shell. (b) The magnitudes of the k 3-weighted Fourier-transformed Ga K-edge EXAFS spectra of Ga-MH-ZSM-5-x, Ga foil and β-Ga2O3 samples. (c) The wavelet transform of the k 3-weighted EXAFS spectra of Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.13, Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.30, Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.47, Ga-MH-ZSM-5-1.62, Ga foil and β-Ga2O3 samples. (d) 71Ga MAS NMR spectra of Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.13, Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.3, Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.47 and Ga-MH-ZSM-5-1.6. (e) Optimized structures for ion-exchanging [Ga(OH)2]+ and [Ga(OH)]2+ cations in Ga-MH-ZSM-5. (f) Schematic illustrations of two or one Brønsted protons exchanged with one Ga3+ cation to form [Ga(OH)]2+ and [Ga(OH)2]+, respectively. (g) Relationship between the content of Brønsted protons exchanged with Ga3+ cations, as determined by comparing the bridged OH vibration band areas at 3610 cm–1 (IR) of Ga-MH-ZSM-x samples with that of MH-ZSM-5, and the Ga/Al ratio of Ga-MH-ZSM-5-x samples (black dotted lines refers to the faction of two Brønsted H+ exchanged with one Ga3+ cations in total Brønsted H+). Aromatization of light alkanes is a value-added process in both petrochemical and coal chemical industries. Here, single [Ga(OH)]2+ ion-exchanged mesoporous hollow-structured ZSM-5 (Ga-MH-ZSM-5) material was prepared, and it shows unprecedented catalytic performance in light alkane aromatization, considering activity, product selectivity and catalytic stability. The average aromatics yields in ethane aromatization at 600 °C and WHSV of 0.8 h–1 within 28 h and in propane aromatization at 580 °C and WHSV of 1.1 h–1 within 20 h reach ~18.4% and ~70.8% with benzene, toluene and xylenes (BTX) accounting for ~96% and ~88% of aromatics, respectively. Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.41 gave a TON for formation of aromatics (TONaromatics) from propane as high as 57479, whereas the reported catalysts maximally show a TONaromatics of 5514. This also holds true for ethane aromatization; the TONaromatics obtained on Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.41 was ≥ 3845 in contrast to ≤ 392 on reported non-noble metal catalysts. The catalytic activity of Ga-MH-ZSM-5 highly depends on Ga species structures. [Ga(OH)]2+ ions are predominant species at Ga loading ≤ 0.3 wt%, while more [Ga(OH)2]+ and GaO x oligomers are formed with increasing Ga content. Upon reduction with H2, [Ga(OH)]2+ and [Ga(OH)2]+ are transformed into [GaH]2+ and [GaH2]+ species, which show a propane dehydrogenation rate of 300 and 15 times of that of Brønsted acid sites respectively. The light alkanes are mainly dehydrogenated into light olefins on [GaH]2+ species, and then, oligomerized and cyclized into (alkyl)cycloalkanes on H+ sites, which is followed by possible ring expansion on H+ and sequential dehydrogenations into aromatics primarily on [GaH]2+. Graphical Abstract Single Ga3+ species has been successfully located at the ion-exchanged sites of mesoporous hollow-structured ZSM-5. This catalyst shows unprecedented catalytic performance in light alkane aromatization, and the catalytic role of Ga species and H+ was clarified. Keywords Light alkane aromatization Mesoporous hollow-structured H-ZSM-5 Isolated Ga species Active site Reaction mechanism 1 Introduction Aromatics, especially benzene, toluene and xylenes (BTX), are basic building units for producing a wide range of industrially important chemicals, e.g. phenol, carboxybenzene, phthalic anhydride, and isophthalic acid etc. [1]. They are traditionally obtained from the catalytic reforming or cracking of naphtha at harsh reaction conditions. Recently, more and more attentions have been paid to hydrogenation of CO/CO2 or conversion of methanol to aromatics, but these processes produce large numbers of CO2/CO and complex hydrocarbon byproducts, which result in lower aromatics yield and economic efficiency [2–4]. The large-scale exploitation of shale gas and the tail gases of C1 compounds (CO, CO2 and CH3OH) conversion to commodity chemicals, e.g. Fisher-Tropsch synthesis, offer another way to produce commodity chemicals, as these gases contain considerable amounts of light alkanes. Thus, direct dehydrogenation or oxidative dehydrogenation of light alkanes to light olefins has attracted great attention [5,6], and the dehydrogenation of propane to propene has been industrialized. In comparison, aromatization of light alkanes has not been made a significant progress yet, although many researches have devoted to this project. This is because this process is far more complex; which involves in not only cracking or dehydrogenation of light alkanes to light olefins but also parallel and tandem reactions of olefins oligomerization, long-chain alkane/alkene cracking or cyclization, and dehydrogenation and/or hydrogen transfer of cyclic hydrocarbons [7,8]. Ga/ZSM-5 and Zn/ZSM-5 are typical two non-noble metal catalysts for light alkanes aromatization [7–16]. Ga/ZSM-5 gave propane conversion and aromatics selectivity in the ranges of 25%–55.7% and of 52.2%–69%, while Zn/ZSM-5 showed propane conversion and aromatics selectivity between 43.2% and 67% and in the region from 29.2% to 55.4%, respectively, depending on the reaction conditions. Compared with Ga/ZSM-5, Zn/ZSM-5 exhibits much lower catalytic stability due to loss of Zn species that arises from formation of ZnO and further reduction to metallic Zn [17]. Therefore, it is highly imperative to develop a highly selective and stable light alkanes aromatics catalyst through clear understanding of reaction mechanism. On Ga/ZSM-5, propane is proposed to be firstly dehydrogenated to propene on Ga species, and then, converted into aromatics. The dehydrogenation of propane to propene is assumed to be the rate-determining step of the propane aromatization [9]. Therefore, the catalytic performances of various types of Ga species, including [GaO]+, [Ga2O2]2+, [Ga(OH)]2+, [Ga(OH)2]+, [GaH2]+, [GaH]2+, Ga+ and GaO x cluster, have been extensively investigated by combining kinetic study, in situ spectroscopies and density functional theory (DFT) computations [12,15,16,18–28]. The state of Ga species in ZSM-5 is related to its introduction method and pretreatment conditions. Generally, Ga species is introduced in H-ZSM-5 by the incipient wetness impregnation method (the obtained material is designated as Ga/ZSM-5). However, this method gives the material with different types of Ga species, including [Ga(OH)]2+, [Ga(OH)2]+, GaO x nanoclusters and Ga nanoparticles, despite that reduction of the material before propane dehydrogenation may lead to formation of more Ga+ species [19]. This makes it very difficult to identify the active sites and estimate the catalytic activity of various types of Ga species [7]. It has been shown that the formic acid impregnation and the ion-exchanged methods give the sample more [GaO]+ species than the incipient wetness impregnation method [10,11]. Regardless of this, appreciable amounts of Ga2O3 clusters are still present in the prepared sample. In order to obtain highly dispersed or isolated Ga species on H-ZSM-5, attempts have been made to introduce Ga species by chemical vapor deposition (CVD) of trimethyl gallium (TMG) or GaCl3. In this way, Ga species can effectively substitute Brønsted acid protons of H-ZSM-5 in the form of mononuclear dimethyl gallium species ([Ga(CH3)2]+). Rane and co-workers found that the TMG species in H-ZSM-5 could be reduced to [GaH2]+ species by H2 at high temperature, which is confirmed by operando XANE spectroscopy [18]. However, this type of Ga species is not stable in the absence of hydrogen and slowly decomposed into Ga+ cations. DFT calculations reveal that [GaO]+ species is more active than reduced Ga+ for dehydrogenation of light alkanes due to significantly lower activation energy barrier, although it is quickly deactivated as a result of difficult regeneration of [GaO]+ species at non-oxidative conditions [28]. This is supported by the in situ DRIFTS result that [GaH2]+ ions were formed in Ga/ZSM-5 at aromatization temperature in hydrogen atmosphere [16]. The hybrid quantum mechanics/molecular mechanics computation results show that [GaH2]+ and [GaH]2+ are more active than H+ and Ga+ for dehydrogenation of ethane [21]. It is substantiated by the kinetic study result obtained with Langmuir-Hinshelwood model; propane dehydrogenation and cracking both preferentially occur on the [GaH]2+ species, and both reaction rates are proportional to [GaH]2+ cations, but independent of Ga content [26]. However, Rodrigues and Faro Júnior thought that Ga+ might be the active species, while [GaH2]+ species was not as it disappeared in the presence of propane [16]. Therefore, the real active sites in Ga/ZSM-5 are still in debate because it is a challenge to fabricate Ga/ZSM-5 with single Ga3+ species. Here, a mesoporous hollow-structured Ga-MH-ZSM-5 with single Ga3+ species was facilely prepared by the simple ion-exchanged method (Fig. 1(a) ). It not only makes it possible of identification of active sites, quantitative estimation of the catalytic activities of the three types of Ga species, viz. [GaH]2+, [GaH2]+ and GaO x clusters, and regulation of Ga species structure in the catalyst, but also shows unprecedented catalytic performance for light alkanes aromatization. In propane aromatization, propane conversion and aromatics selectivity reach as high as 97.4%–88.5% and 78.2 wt%–73.6 wt% respectively at 580 °C, 1 atm and WHSV of 1.1 h–1 within 20 h. More interestingly, about 88% of aromatics are BTX. As a result, the yields of total aromatics and BTX reach ca. 76.2 wt% and 67 wt% respectively, being much higher than those of reported noble and non-noble metal catalysts [10–12,29–41]. In addition, this catalyst also shows exceptionally high catalytic activity, product selectivity and catalytic stability in ethane aromatization; the ethane conversion and aromatics selectivity reach ~25% and ~73.5% respectively at 600 °C, 1 atm, WHSV of 0.8 h–1. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation 2.1.1 Synthesis of parent ZSM-5 Parent ZSM-5 was synthesized by the hydrothermal method. The synthesis gel was prepared with tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS), tetrapropylammonium hydroxide (TPAOH, 25 wt%) and NaAlO2 according to the composition of 1 SiO2:0.02 Al2O3: 0.25 TPAOH:30 H2O. After being stirred at room temperature for 7 h, it was transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave. The crystallization was statically carried out at 170 °C for 4 d. The product was centrifuged, washed with deionized water, dried at 100 °C overnight, and calcined at 600 °C for 10 h in air. 2.1.2 Synthesis of hollow-structured ZSM-5 In a typical batch, 1 g ZSM-5 sample was suspended in 3.5 g TPAOH solution (25 wt%) and 4 g H2O. The mixture was treated at 170 °C for 24 h under static conditions. The solid product was calcined at 600 °C for 6 h in static air. 2.1.3 Synthesis of mesoporous hollow-structured ZSM-5 The hollow-structured ZSM-5 was treated with 0.1 mol/L NaOH solution at a liquid/solid ratio of 50 mL/g for 15 min at ∼65 °C. Then, the zeolite suspension was immediately cooled in an ice bath, and centrifuged to collect the solid, which was subsequently washed with deionized water until the filtrate pH value of ≈7. The obtained solid was dried at 100 °C overnight, and calcined at 500 °C for 4 h in air. 2.1.4 Preparation of H-form zeolites The hollow-structured ZSM-5 and mesoporous hollow-structured ZSM-5 were ion-exchanged with aqueous NH4NO3 solution (1 mol/L, m liquid/m solid = 40) at 80 °C for 4 h. The obtained solids were dried at 100 °C and calcined at 550 °C for 6 h, and designated as HH-ZSM-5 and MH-ZSM-5, respectively. 2.1.5 Supporting of Ga species on MH-ZSM-5 The Ga species were supported on MH-ZSM-5 by the ion-exchange method. The MH-ZSM-5 was ion-exchanged with different concentrations of aqueous Ga(NO3)3 solution under reflux conditions to achieve the Ga contents intermediated between 0.082 wt% and 1.62 wt%. The obtained materials were donated to Ga-MH-ZSM-5-x with x representing the Ga content in the sample, e.g. Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.30 represents the Ga content in Ga-MH-ZSM-5 is 0.30 wt%. 2.1.6 Supporting of Ga species on H-ZSM-5 For comparison, the Ga species were also supported on H-ZSM-5 by the ion-exchange method used for preparation of Ga-MH-ZSM-5-x. The Ga content was controlled to 0.30 wt%, and the obtained sample was denoted to Ga-H-ZSM-5-0.30. 2.2 Catalyst characterizations The crystal structure, texture properties, morphology, acidity, and Ga3+ coordination states of prepared samples were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), N2 sorption, transmission electron microscopy (TEM)/high-resolution TEM (HRTEM), aberration-corrected high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) elemental mapping, 27Al magic angle spinning nuclear magnetic resonance (MAS NMR), 29Si MAS NMR, 71Ga MAS NMR, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), pyridine-adsorption IR spectroscopy (Py-IR), temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS,) X-ray absorption near edge structure/extended X-ray absorption fine structure (XANES/EXAFS), and details can be found in Supplementary data. 2.3 Catalysts evaluation Catalytic performance of various samples for light alkane aromatization was carried out at atmospheric pressure in a fixed-bed reactor (i.d. 10 mm) typically loaded 1.0–2.0 g sample (20–40 mesh). The reaction was performed at 540–600 °C and light alkane weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of 0.8–1.4 h−1 (light alkane/nitrogen molar ratio of 1/2.5). The gaseous and liquid products were separated by a cold trap (–5–0 °C). The gaseous products including H2, CH4, and light olefins and paraffins were on-line analyzed by a gas chromatograph (GC) (Agilent 7890A) equipped with one thermal conductivity detector (TCD, MoleSieve 5A column, 3 m × 1/16 inch × 1 μm) and two flame ionization detectors (FIDs, GC-OxyPlot column, 10 m × 530 μm × 10 μm; Al2O3 column, 50 m × 530 μm × 15 μm). The liquid products including C5 + aliphatic hydrocarbons and aromatics were analyzed by another Angilent 7890A gas chromatograph equipped with an FID and a capillary column (Agilent 19091S-001, 50 m × 200 μm × 0.5 μm). The light alkane conversion and the product selectivity were calculated as below: X alkane = (∑Ci – C alkane)/∑Ci × 100% S i = Ci /(∑Ci – C alkane) × 100% where X alkane (%) is light alkane conversion, Si (wt%) is the selectivity of the target product i; Ci and C alkane (wt%) are the corrected mass concentrations of species i and light alkane respectively. The deactivated catalyst was in situ regenerated at 540 °C for 48 h under air atmosphere (50 mL/min). The regenerated catalyst was purged by a N2 flow (50 mL/min) for 5 h before the next catalytic test. 2.4 Temperature programmed surface reaction (TPSR) TPSR of propene aromatization was conducted in a U-type quartz tube micro-reactor loading 20 mg catalyst. The reaction temperature was ramped from room temperature to 440 °C at a rate of 5 °C/min in propene (1 mL/min) and N2 (160 mL/min) flow. Prior to the reaction, the samples were pretreated at 500 °C under N2 (for MH-ZSM-5 sample) or 10%H2/Ar (for Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.3 sample) for 1 h. The gaseous products were collected with gas sample bags (Teflon, collect 30 sec at each temperature) and then detected by GC-MS (Shimadzu GCMS-QP2010) equipped with a capillary column (Rtx-5MS, 60 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm)). TPSR of propane aromatization was conducted in a U-type quartz tube micro-reactor loading 40 mg catalyst. The reaction temperature was ramped from room temperature to 550 °C at a rate of 3 °C/min in propane (0.5 mL/min) and N2 (160 mL/min) flow. Prior to the reaction, the samples were pretreated at 500 °C under N2 (for MH-ZSM-5 sample) or 10%H2/Ar (for Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.3 sample) for 1 h. The gaseous products were analyzed by an IONICON proton-transfer-reaction time-of-flight mass spectrometry 4000 (PTR-TOF-MS 4000). PTR-TOF-MS uses H3O+ as a primary ion and a resolution (m/Δm based on the definition given by the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry) of ~4000. The drift tube pressure was 2.7 mbar; the drift tube temperature was 80 °C and the drift tube voltage is 740 V, corresponding to a (E/N) electric field strength/gas number density of 139.2 Townsend (Td, 1 Td = 10–17 V cm2). The water flow in the drift tube was 6.5 sccm. Mass spectra cycles were recorded once per 1000 millisecond. Analytes with a proton affinity greater than that of water react with primary ions (~99%): R + H3O+ → RH+ + H2O where R is analyte of volatile organic compounds (VOCs). 2.5 DFT calculations. The kinetics and thermodynamics of propane conversion were calculated with the Gaussian 09.D01 package on the basis of two 120 T cluster models. The model, ONIOM (ωB97X-D/(6-31G (d, p)): PM6), was used in all geometry optimizations and frequency calculations. The 14 T active region and the reactant molecules were treated as the high layer and fully relaxed, whereas the rest structure was served as the low layer, and consequently fixed. All transition states (TS) were guessed by the OPT = TS. Subsequently, the obtained configuration was confirmed by the quasi-internal reaction coordinate (quasi-IRC) approach to verify that each authentic TS bridges the corresponding reactants and products. The TSs were the first-order saddle point of potential energy surface with only a single imaginary frequency. The obtained reactants and products were situated at the energy minima points of potential energy surface with only real frequencies. The single-point energy calculations with the 6-311G(2df,2p) basis set were refined by the ωB97X-D functional including dispersion interactions to obtain accurate interaction energies. The free energies (ΔG), enthalpies (ΔH) and entropies (ΔS) were computed from the ωB97X-D/6-311G (2df, 2p) total electronic energy and the thermal correction from the ONIOM (ωB97X-D/(6-31G (d, p)): PM6) frequency calculation by using the partial Hessian vibrational analysis (PHVA) method at 500 °C, which included the atoms that were relaxed during the geometry optimization. The rate constant (k) at 500 °C was calculated with the classical transition-state theory (TST) by following the equation of k = k B T h exp ( - Δ G int ≠ / R T ) = k B T h exp ( Δ S int ≠ / R ) exp ( - Δ H int ≠ / R T ) where kB is the Boltzmann’s constant, h is the Planck’s constant, and ΔG int ≠ , ΔH int ≠ and ΔS int ≠ are the changes of standard molar Gibbs free energy, enthalpy, and entropy at 500 °C between the reactants and the transition state (TS). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physicochemical properties of mesoporous Ga-MH-ZSM-5-x Fig. S1 shows the XRD patterns of mesoporous Ga-MH-ZSM-5-x samples with x representing Ga loading (wt%). All the samples are single ZSM-5 phase with high crystallinity. The absence of Ga2O3 diffraction peaks indicates that Ga species are highly dispersed on ZSM-5 [12]. This is supported by their slight effect on the specific surface area and pore volume of ZSM-5, despite that an obvious decline was observed for Ga-MH-ZSM-5-1.62. The insignificant difference from the parent MH-ZSM-5 in micropore surface area and micropore volume suggests that most of Ga species are located on the external surfaces or at the mesopores and/or hollow void space (Table S1). The crystals of parent ZSM-5 are highly dispersed with average size of ca. 240 × 300 nm, although some nanocrystals (ca. 30 nm) attach on their external surface (Figs. 1(b)–(d)). After recrystallization, uniform hollow particles with shell of ≈ 30 nm thick were obtained. It has been shown that the interior of parent ZSM-5 particle is more desilicated by OH– species than the exterior due to rich Al distribution on the exterior [42] This results in the recrystallization of dissolved silicate species around crystal external surface and formation of hollow particles. It is substantiated by location of much more Al and Ga species on the crystal shell for Ga/HH-ZSM-5 and Ga/MH-ZSM-5 (Figs. 1(l) and 1(m)), whereas Ga/H-ZSM-5 prepared by the impregnation method possesses much more uniform Ga and Al elemental distributions over the whole crystals (Fig. 1(k)). Further treatment with aqueous NaOH solution generates abundant mesopores (Figs. 1(d)–(f)). The abundant mesopores in Ga/MH-ZSM-5 is confirmed by the presence of a large hysteresis loop in its N2 sorption isotherms and a sharp peak around 4 nm in pore size distribution profile, which is, however, absent or very weak in the other two samples (Fig. S2). Atomic-resolution iDPC-STEM images indicate that Ga species are highly dispersed in the micropores of Ga-MH-ZSM-5 (Figs. 1(h)–(j)), with the particle size of around 0.23 ± 0.03 nm (Fig. 1(g)). ICP measurements show that the Ga contents in the three samples intermediate between 0.94% and 1.01%, being similar to the theoretical value of 1.0% (Table S2). However, XPS analysis result (Table S2) reveals that the external surfaces of Ga/HH-ZSM-5, and particularly Ga/H-ZSM-5 are rich of Ga, while that of Ga/MH-ZSM-5 has a lower Ga content. The steric and electronic constraints of large aqueous Ga3+ complex molecule make it difficult to diffuse into ZSM-5 micropores. The presence of large numbers of mesopores in Ga/MH-ZSM-5 facilitates its diffusion into the sample, and thus, increases the amount of Ga species in the interior. 3.2 Catalytic performances of Ga-impregnated samples and Ga-MH-ZSM-5-x The catalytic results of Ga-impregnated samples (Ga/H-ZSM-5, Ga/HH-ZSM-5, Ga/MH-ZSM-5) for propane aromatization are summarized in Fig. 2 . The mesoporous Ga/MH-ZSM-5 sample exhibits higher propane conversion and aromatics selectivity than the other two samples, confirming the superiority of mesoporous structure (Table S3). Figs. S3(a) and 3(b) shows the time-resolved FTIR spectra for adsorption of p-xylene on parent H-ZSM-5 and MH-ZSM-5 zeolites. The two intense vibration bands at ca. 1380 and 1519 cm–1 are characteristic of absorbed p-xylene. Clearly, these two bands more speedily increase in intensity for MH-ZSM-5 than for H-ZSM-5. This demonstrates that MH-ZSM-5 adsorbs p-xylene at a higher rate, which is directly substantiated by the dependence of normalized intensity of the 1519 cm–1 band on t 1/2 (Fig. S3(c)). A good linear relationship between Q t/Q inf. and t 1/2 in the range of Qt /Q inf. of 0–0.6 reveals that the diffusion coefficient of p-xylene in MH-ZSM-5 is 2.4 times of that in H-ZSM-5 (7.74 × 10–14 vs. 3.17× 10–14 cm2/s, Fig. S3(d) and Table S4). It is further corroborated by the intelligent gravimetric analysis (IGA) result; the toluene diffusion coefficient in MH-ZSM-5 is about 3.1 times of that in H-ZSM-5 (1.12 × 10–12 vs. 3.59 × 10–13 cm2 s–1 (Fig. S4). The higher diffusivity of MH-ZSM-5 is expected to significantly alleviate the formation of coke species, which is substantiated by the TG/DTG, DR UV-vis and Raman spectral results of Ga/MH-ZSM-5 and Ga/H-ZSM-5; the former sample produces less amounts of polycyclic aromatics species, and displays a carbon deposition rate of ~1/2 of that of the latter sample at the same conditions (Figs. S5–S7 and Table S4). It is further manifested in the catalytic performance difference of Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.30 and Ga-H-ZSM-5-0.30 (Fig. S8(c)). It is clear that Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.30 exhibits much higher propane conversion and aromatics selectivity than Ga-H-ZSM-5-0.30 although these two samples have highly comparable crystal structure and acidity (Figs. S8(a), (b) and Table S5). Another interesting point is that considerably more Ga species are deposited on the external surface for Ga-H-ZSM-5-0.30 (Table S5), whereas they are mostly located in the interior of framework for Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.30. This is expected as the abundant mesopores of Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.30 facilitates the diffusion of Ga aquo ions onto its inner surface. These results definitely confirm that the higher catalytic performance of Ga-MH-ZSM-5-x is related to its mesoporous hollow structure. Fig. 3 compares the catalytic results of MH-ZSM-5 and Ga-MH-ZSM-5-x with different Ga content for aromatization of propane. Clearly, Ga-MH-ZSM-5-x samples show significantly higher propane conversion and aromatics selectivity than MH-ZSM-5, although the propane conversion and the aromatics selectivity both show a volcanic curve with the Ga content and get to the maximum value at Ga content of around 0.3–0.47 wt% (Figs. 3(a) and (b)). The BTX fraction in the aromatics is ca. 87%–91% for all of these samples. The aromatics yield of Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.3 reaches 38 wt% at 540 °C, being about 24 times of that obtained on MH-ZSM-5 (Fig. 3(a)). The main by-products of MH-ZSM-5 are methane, ethene and propene (Fig. S9), while most of light olefins are consumed on Ga-MH-ZSM-5 samples despite that the selectivity of methane and ethane reduces with the Ga content as a result of weakening Brønsted acidity. The similar amount of methane to that of ethane and ethene obtained on MH-ZSM-5 sample indicates a severe cracking of propane. In addition, the weaker Brønsted acidity of Ga-MH-ZSM-5-x than of MH-ZSM-5 attenuates hydrogen transfer reactions. Thus, remarkably higher aromatics yield was obtained on Ga-MH-ZSM-5-x than on MH-ZSM-5. The detection of much larger amounts of light olefins on MH-ZSM-5 than on Ga-MH-ZSM-5-x indicates that aromatization of light olefins on these two catalysts occurs via different pathways. The presence of more ethene than of propene in effluent over all the samples is due to its lower reactivity. Interestingly, all the samples were kept nearly stable with the time-on-stream in both propane conversion and aromatics selectivity at least within 50 h (Fig. S9). This holds true for neat propane aromatization; the propane conversion and the aromatics selectivity intermediated in the range of around 80%–93% and 70 wt%–72.9 wt% respectively, at 580 °C and WHSV of 1.8 h–1 before 50 h (Fig. S10). We further evaluated the long-term stability of Ga-MH-ZSM-5 catalyst for propane aromatization. As expected, the initial propane conversion and aromatics selectivity were 88.5% and 76.6 wt% respectively (TOS = 4 h, Fig. S11), although they gradually decreased thereafter. Nevertheless, the propane conversion of ~50% and aromatics selectivity of ~55 wt% were still obtained even at the reaction time of 244 h (~10 d). Notably, light olefins are the dominant by-products with the selectivity of ~30% at 244 h. It suggests that the deactivation of Ga-MH-ZSM-5 is mainly due to the carbon deposition on acid sites. This is confirmed by the catalytic results obtained within four repeated runs with regeneration; the catalytic activity, product selectivity and catalytic stability of Ga-MH-ZSM-5 were well restored in each repeated run, evidencing that Ga-MH-ZSM-5 samples are highly stable and recyclable (Fig. S12). Upon optimization of reaction conditions, the propane conversion and aromatics selectivity of Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.41 were increased to 97.4%–88.5% and 78.2 wt%–73.6 wt% respectively, which are approaching to the thermodynamic equilibrium values of propane conversion (99.8%) and aromatics selectivity (88.6 wt%) at 580 °C, 1 atm and N2/C3H8 of 2.5/1 (vol/vol)) (Fig. S13), with BTX accounting for ca. 88% of total aromatics (Figs. 3(c) and 3(d)). As a result, the BTX and total aromatics yields reached ca. 67 wt% and 76.2 wt% respectively, which are, to the best of our knowledge, higher than those of all the reported noble and non-noble metal catalysts for propane aromatization (Fig. 3(e), Fig. S14 and Table S6). In particular, Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.41 afforded an exceptionally high TONaromatics (turnover number for generating aromatics, calculated on the basis of the molar amount of Ga species) of 57479 within 50 h (C3H8 conversion was lowered to 80%), whereas the best reported zeolite-supported Ga and Zn catalysts maximally gave a TONaromatics of 5514 at deactivation time of 25 h (C3H8 conversion was decreased to ~48%) (Fig. 3(f)). Even if the TONaromatics was obtained by dividing the totally generated aromatics by the catalyst weight, Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.41 shows a TONaromatics as high as ~3.67 times of that of the best reported Ga- or Zn-based catalyst (Fig. S15). To more directly compare the catalytic performances of our prepared Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.41 and reported Ga- and Zn-based catalysts, several typical reported catalysts were prepared and evaluated at the same conditions. Clearly, the propane conversions on 6wt%Zn0.2wt%Sn0.1wt%Pt/ZSM-5 (prepared by the impregnation method), 1wt%Ga/H-ZSM-5 and 4wt% Cr1wt%Ga/H-ZSM-5 were quickly decreased from 99%, 88.2% and 68.3% to 56%, 36% and 26.2%, respectively, within 50 h (Fig. S16), whereas that on Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.41 just lowered from 93% to 80%. The higher catalytic stability of Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.41 is also manifested on the aromatics selectivity. It shows an aromatics selectivity of 72.9 wt%–69.2 wt% in contrast to 53.5 wt%–45.0 wt% of 6wt%Zn0.2wt% Sn0.1wt%Pt/ ZSM-5, 63–40.8 wt% of 1wt%Ga/H-ZSM-5 and 39.1 wt%–22.7 wt% of 4wt%Cr1wt%Ga/H-ZSM-5. These results give definite evidences for the superiority of Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.41 in the activity, aromatics selectivity and catalytic stability. Another notable point is that the Ga-MH-ZSM-5-x catalysts can also effectively catalyze ethane aromatization. At 580 °C, 1 atm and WHSVethane of 0.8 h–1, Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.41 showed an ethane conversion of ~22% and an aromatics selectivity of ca.73.4 wt% (Figs. S17(a), S17(b)), with ca. 92.5% of total aromatics being BTX. After reaction of 14 h, the temperature was raised to 600 °C, the ethane conversion was increased to ~25% with the selectivity to aromatics kept at ~73.5 wt% and the BTX content in aromatics elevated to more than 96 wt% at least with 28 h (TONaromatics calculated on the basis of Ga content and catalysts weight were larger than 3845 and 4.6 respectively), which are significantly higher than those of reported Ga-supporting zeolite catalysts [43–46]. Although Zn/hollow-HZSM-5 initially exhibit higher ethane conversion at 575 °C, 1 atm and WHSV of 0.6 h–1, its catalytic stability is very lower; the ethane conversion and aromatics selectivity decreased from 51.1% and 72.1% to 22.5% and 13.2%, respectively, on Zn/hollow-H-ZSM-5 within 25 h (TONaromatics obtained with Zn content and catalyst weight were smaller than 392 and 2.0 respectively) (Fig. S15(b) and Fig. S17(c)) [43]. As for PtM/H-ZSM-5 samples (M = Fe, Sn and Ge), one result obtained at 630 °C, 1 atm and GHSV of 1000 h−1 was only provided, and hence, its catalytic stability cannot be compared for the moment [47]. Interestingly, ethene is the main by-product with selectivity of 16 wt%–19 wt% on Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.41. The above results corroborate that Ga-MH-ZSM-5-x samples are potential for aromatization of light alkanes (Table S6). 3.3 Structures of Ga species in Ga-MH-ZSM-5-x samples Fig. 4(a) displays the XANES spectra of Ga-MH-ZSM-5-x samples, and for comparison, of β-Ga2O3. The related Ga K-edge energies are listed in Table S7. A peak is present at about 10376 eV in the XANES spectra of Ga-MH-ZSM-5-x samples when x is less than 0.47, while another broad one was also observed at 10378 eV in the spectra of β-Ga2O3 and Ga-MH-ZSM-5-x samples with x ≥ 0.7. These two peaks are assigned to tetrahedral and octahedral Ga3+ species respectively [27]. It reveals that almost of all the Ga species in the former samples are highly dispersed in ion-exchanged positions with a tetrahedral coordination, whereas the latter samples contain both tetrahedral ion-exchanging Ga species and Ga2O3 clusters that increase with the Ga content, as corroborated by the enhancement of the peak at 10378 eV. Fitted k 3-weighted EXAFS spectra of Ga-MH-ZSM-5-x samples show an intense peak between 1 and 2 Å in the R-space (Figs. 4(b), Fig. S18). It is corresponding to the backscattering of O atoms coordinated to Ga3+ ions. Notably, another intense peak was observed between 2.5 and 3.5 Å in the Fourier-transformed EXAFS spectra of Ga-MH-ZSM-5-1.10 and –1.62. This peak is due to the backscattering of next-neighbor Ga atoms in Ga−O−Ga linkage, as substantiated by the spectrum of β-Ga2O3 [27]. It confirms the existence of highly dispersed GaO x clusters on these two samples, which is further substantiated by the increase of the coordination number (CN) of Ga3+ ions and the average Ga–O interatomic distance in Ga-MH-ZSM-5-x samples with the Ga content (Table S8) [48]. The wavelet transforms of the k 3-weighted EXAFS spectra further reveal that the Ga-MH-ZSM-5 samples with Ga loading ≤ 0.47% show only the first coordination-shell peak, ascribed to Ga–O coordination, at about 1.5 Å (Fig. 4(c)), giving another piece of evidence for the presence of sole isolated Ga3+ species. The states of Ga species in Ga-MH-ZSM-5-x samples were further probed by 71Ga solid-state NMR spectroscopy [49]. The spectra were fitted with a Q mas 1/2 model (Fig. 4(d)). All the samples display a signal at chemical shift of 150 ppm, indicative of presence of Ga species with a low coordination [50,51]. It has been reported that the signal at approximately 160 ppm is characteristic of framework Ga atoms in MFI zeolite [52–54]. Considering preparation of Ga-MH-ZSM-5-x samples by the ion-exchange method, incorporation of Ga atoms in ZSM-5 framework is impossible. Therefore, it can be deduced that this type of Ga species have a tetrahedral coordination and are located at the ion-exchange positions in the form of [Ga(OH)]2+ or [Ga(OH)2]+ cation [55,56]. The shoulder signal at 30 ppm is assigned to Ga species octahedrally coordinated to oxygen species [50,51]. It enhances with the Ga content, being consistent with the XANES and EXAFS results. The above XAFS and MAS NMR results show that [Ga(OH)]2+ and [Ga(OH)2]+ are the primary gallium species if no agglomeration occurs. Theoretical calculations reveal that the Ga3+ ions in [Ga(OH)]2+ species is coordinated by one OH group and three framework O atoms with Ga−O interatomic distances of 1.76, 1.89, 1.90 and 1.97 Å (Fig. 4(e)), while that of [Ga(OH)2]+ is coordinated by two OH groups and two framework O atoms with Ga−O interatomic distances of 1.78, 1.79, 1.95 and 1.96 Å. The average Ga−O distances of [Ga(OH)]2+ and [Ga(OH)2]+ species are 1.88 and 1.87 Å respectively, which are in agreement with the EXAFS fitting results of Ga-MH-ZSM-5-x samples with x ≤ 0.47 (Table S8). This further demonstrates that almost of all the Ga species in these Ga-MH-ZSM-5-x samples are [Ga(OH)]2+ and/or [Ga(OH)2]+ cations. However, when x is larger than 0.7, the samples contain GaO x clusters besides these two types of Ga species, as demonstrated by their longer average Ga−O distances and higher CNs (Table S8). The content of Brønsted acid sites exchanged with Ga3+ ions (designated as H+) can be roughly estimated by comparing the IR band area of Brønsted acid stretching vibration at 3610 cm–1 with that of MH-ZSM-5 (Eq. (1)) [27] (Fig. 4(f) and Fig. S19). (1) = 1 - i n t e r g r a t e d a r e a o f 3610 c m - 1 band of Ga - MH - ZSM - 5 - x i n t e g r a t e d a r e a o f 3610 c m - 1 band of MH - ZSM - 5 Fig. 4(g) clearly shows a linear relationship between the content of Brønsted acid sites exchanged with Ga3+ ions and the Ga/AlF ratio of Ga-MH-ZSM-5-x samples when x is ≤ 0.3. The slope of the fitted line is ≈ 2, indicative of dominant presence of [Ga(OH)]2+ species that exchanges two Brønsted protons. Increase of the Ga content to 0.47% leads to a deviation of the exchanged H+ content from the fitted line. The red dashed line in Fig. S20 represents one Brønsted H+ exchanged with one Ga3+ ion when the content of Ga species is higher than 0.3%. Clearly, the Ga-MH-ZSM-5-x samples with x between 0.38–0.47 are sited in this line, indicative of formation of [Ga(OH)2]+ species, as supported by detection of no octahedral Ga species. When the Ga content in the samples is ≥ 0.7 wt%, elevation of Ga amount cannot raise the ion-exchange degree, implying that more introduced Ga species are agglomerated into GaO x clusters. The above XANES, EXAFS, FT-IR, 71Ga MAS NMR and DFT computation results reveal that [Ga(OH)]2+ is the dominant Ga species in the Ga-MH-ZSM-5-x samples at x ≤ 0.30, while the samples with 0.30 < x ≤ 0.47 contain mainly [Ga(OH)]2+ and [Ga(OH)2]+ species. In the cases of the samples at x ≥ 0.7, GaO x clusters are formed. The single Ga3+ species sited at the ion-exchanged positions of Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.30 accounts well for its higher catalytic stability in combination with the zeolite microstructure, as it is structurally stable due to its bonding to zeolite framework via three oxygen atoms (Fig. 4(f)). Another notable point is that it facilitates the accurate determination of the catalytic activities of different types of Ga species, as their structures can be finely tuned by controlling their ion-exchanged contents. 3.4 Effect of H2 pretreatment on the catalytic performance of Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.3 for propane aromatization Guisnet and Gnep found that propane aromatization generated considerable amounts of hydrogen with the weight percent of ca. 5.9 wt% (Cyclar process) [8]. This is more significant on the Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.41 sample. It gave a hydrogen weight percent of 7.8 wt% at 580 °C, 1 atm and WHSV of 1.1 h–1. It has been reported that [Ga(OH)]2+ and [Ga(OH)2]+ ions could be reduced to [GaH]2+ and [GaH2]+ ions respectively by the generated H2 in the reaction process [16,26], which makes it highly difficult to identify [GaH]2+, [GaH2]+, [Ga(OH)]2+ or [Ga(OH)2]+ species to be catalytically active sites. In order to clarify that [GaH]2+ or [Ga(OH)]2+ species is the catalytic site, Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.3 was pretreated in 10% H2/Ar at 500 °C for 5 min and 1 h, respectively, before catalyzing the reaction. For comparison, the sample was calcined at 500 °C for 1 h in N2 without H2 pretreatment so as to keep gallium species to be [Ga(OH)]2+. Fig. 5(a) shows that the propane conversion obtained over the sample calcined in N2 without H2 pretreatment gradually increases from ~6% to a steady platform of ~14% at reaction time of 550 min. However, this induction period was significantly shortened to 100 min when the sample was only treated at 500 °C for 5 min in 10% H2/Ar. Further increase of the H2-treatmented time to 1 h nearly eliminated the induction period. This supports the progressive transformation of [Ga(OH)]2+ and [Ga(OH)2]+ into [GaH]2+ and [GaH2]+ respectively by the generated H2 in the reaction process, which is directly evidenced by in situ FT-IR spectroscopy. After being treated at 500 °C for 1 h in 10% H2/Ar, Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.38 and Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.41 samples show two vibration bands at around 2049 and 2038 cm−1 in the range of 2018−2062 cm−1 (Fig. 5(e)), whereas Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.15 and 0.25 display only the 2049 cm−1 band. These two bands have been assigned to [GaH]2+ and [GaH2]+ species respectively [16,26,57–60]. This is consistent with the fact that the former two samples contain both [Ga(OH)]2+ and [Ga(OH)2]+ species, while the latter one has dominant [Ga(OH)]2+ species. Figs. 5(b) and 5(c) show the product selectivity obtained on the Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.3 and its H2-pretreated counterpart at different reaction time. The H2-treated sample shows nearly constant propene and aromatics selectivity in the whole reaction process. In contrast, the propene selectivity on the H2-untreated Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.3 is monotonically decreased with the time on stream, and leveled off to the value obtained on the H2-pretreated sample at about 350 min. A contrary phenomenon was observed for the aromatic selectivity. The methane selectivity is the same and kept constant on these three samples, indicative of a similar propane cracking activity. It is supported by the finding that the H2 treatment has no great effect on the Brønsted acidity of Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.3 (Fig. S21). The above results suggest that [GaH]2+ species exhibits higher propane dehydrogenation activity than [Ga(OH)]2+. The substantial difference in the selectivity to propene and aromatics in the induction period between the two samples suggests that [GaH]2+ also significantly accelerates propene aromatization. The same ethane selectivity indicates that the contribution of hydrogen transfer reaction to the aromatization over the two samples is similar, which is expectable as they have the nearly same Brønsted acidity. Aromatics are mainly formed through propene oligomerization, cyclization, and subsequent dehydrogenation or hydrogen transfer reaction. This is substantiated by the result that the carbon moles of decreased propene amount are ≈1.2 times of those of increased (aromatics + ethene) amount, while nearly two times of those of increased aromatics amount (Fig. 5(d)). An increase in ethene selectivity in the induction period arises from the more significant scission of long-chain alkenes formed from propene oligomerization on the N2-pretreated sample [61]. This is supported by obtaining a much higher ratio of carbon molar selectivity of (ethene + ethane) to that of methane than theoretical value (5.4/1 vs. 2/1). 3.5 Kinetics for propane aromatization on the H2-pretreated Ga-MH-ZSM-5-x samples The samples selected for kinetic study were labeled in red (Fig. S20). All the Ga3+ species in these samples are dominantly [Ga(OH)]2+ or/and [Ga(OH)2]+ ions. In order to transform all the [Ga(OH)]2+ and [Ga(OH)2]+ species into [GaH]2+ and [GaH2]+ ions respectively, the samples were pretreated at 500 °C for 1 h in 10% H2/Ar (120 mL/min) [26]. The contents of [GaH]2+ and [GaH2]+ species in the Ga-MH-ZSM-5-x catalysts were displayed in Table S9. In the kinetics experiments, the propane conversion of each test was kept below 2.7%. Propene, methane and ethene were the main products with negligible amounts of ethane, butane and butene at 500 °C. The aromatics were not detected in all the tests. Fig. S22 shows the dependence of propene and methane yields on the Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.15 at atmospheric pressure, propane partial pressure of 0.149 kPa and 500 °C on the space time. Apparent reaction rates (mol/(gcat·h)) of propane dehydrogenation was estimated by the slope of propene yield vs. space time [62,63]. Fig. S23 shows that the propane dehydrogenation rates on MH-ZSM-5 and Ga-MH-ZSM-5-x all exhibit a first-order dependence on the propane partial pressure between 0.149 and 0.389 kPa. The slopes of the fitted lines in Fig. S23 are the apparent propane dehydrogenation rate coefficients. On MH-ZSM-5, the apparent rate coefficient (k H2 K H1, mol/(mol H+·s·bar)) was estimated by the slope of the fitted line in Fig. S23(a). As the dominant Ga species in Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.083, Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.15 and Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.25 samples are [GaH]2+ cations, the apparent propane dehydrogenation rate coefficient (k 2 K 1 + k′3 K′1 K′2) (Fig. 6(a) , Schemes S2 and S3) were estimated by the average slope of the fitted lines in Figs. S23(b)–(d). The H2-pretreated Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.38 and -0.41 samples, as is shown above, contain both [GaH]2+ and [GaH2]+ species. Thus, the total propane dehydrogenation rate (r total(dehydrogenation)) was computed by Eq. (2). r total(dehydrogenation) = (k 2 K 1 + k′3 K′1 K′2)[[GaH]2+][C3H8] (2) + k′′2 K′′1[[GaH2]+][C3H8] + k H2 K H1[H+][C3H8] where [H+], [[GaH]2+] and [[GaH2]+] are H+, [GaH]2+ and [GaH2]+ concentrations (mol/gcat.) respectively, [C3H8] is propane partial pressure (bar), and K′2 K′1 (Scheme S4) and k H2 K H1 (Scheme S1) are the apparent rate coefficients on the [GaH2]+ (mol/(mol [GaH2]+·s·bar)) and H+ sites (mol/(mol H+·s·bar)), respectively. K′2 K′1can be obtained with Eq. (2) with the apparent propane dehydrogenation rate coefficient on [GaH]2+ and the slopes of the corresponding fitted lines in Figs. S23(e)–(h). The average value of K′2 K′1 obtained on the Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.38 and Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.41 samples are considered as the apparent propane dehydrogenation rate coefficient on [GaH2]+. Fig. 6(b) shows the relationships between the apparent propane dehydrogenation rate coefficients normalized to H+, [GaH]2+ and [GaH2]+ amounts, respectively, and the Ga contents in the samples. The dehydrogenation rate on the [GaH]2+ is nearly independent on the Ga content (red squares). It is around 17.5 mol/(mol [GaH]2+·s·bar), being about 20 and 300 times as high as those on [GaH2]+ and H+ sites respectively. This shows that [GaH]2+ is the most active sites for dehydrogenation of propane. Table S10 shows the free energy barriers and rate constants of propane dehydrogenation at 500 °C on [GaH]2+ and [GaH2]+ sites. The alkyl mechanism is more favorable than the carbenium mechanism, in agreement with the previous results [25]. In the alkyl mechanism, the first step for formation of [C3H7]− intermediate from adsorbed propane requires 32 and 123 kJ/mol (Figs. 6(c) and (d)), while the second step for the formation of propene needs to overcome 187 and 212 kJ/mol on [GaH]2+ and [GaH2]+ sites, respectively. As a consequence, the intrinsic rate constant for propane dehydrogenation on [GaH]2+ is 3.72 s–1, which is about 49 times of that on [GaH2]+ site (7.61 × 10–2 s–1). This is in good agreement with the kinetics study results (≈20 times), further confirming that [GaH]2+ is much more active than [GaH2]+ for propane dehydrogenation. The reaction mechanism of propane aromatization was investigated by combining GC-MS, PTR-TOF-MS, probe experiments and DFT calculations. Fig. 7 and Fig. S24 displays proposed reaction network of propane aromatization. On the acid sites of H-ZSM-5, propane cracking into ethene and methane (CR1) is more possible than its dehydrogenation into propene (DH1) as a result of lower free energy barrier (179 kJ/mol vs. 230 kJ/mol) [64]. Interestingly, the free energy barrier of DH1 can be decreased to 187 kJ/mol on [GaH]2+ species sited at ion-exchanged positions of H-ZSM-5 (DH2), which makes it comparable and competent of DH1 with CR1, and thus, enhancing the DH1 and suppressing the CR1. This is supported by the fact that Ga-MH-ZSM-5-x shows lower selectivity to ethene and methane than MH-ZSM-5 at the same conditions (Fig. S9). The generated propene and ethene are oligomerized into long-chain alkenes on the Brønsted acid sites of H-ZSM-5 (Fig. 7). Ethene oligomerization to butene (O1) and further to hexene (O2) require free energy barriers of 112 and 88 kJ/mol respectively, while propene dimerization to hexene (O3) needs to overcome a free energy barrier of 100 kJ/mol. In the case of propene and butene oligomerization to heptene (O4), the free energy barrier is about 99 kJ/mol. Notably, ethene oligomerization on [GaH]2+ site requires a free energy barrier of 341 kJ/mol. It is much higher than that on Brønsted acid site (112 kJ/mol), indicating that Brønsted acid sites are the main active sites of olefins oligomerization (Table S11). These calculation results indicate that the produced ethene and propene are easily converted into long-chain alkenes, as consolidated by the propene conversion probe experiments that gave large amounts of C6 and C7 alkenes in the initial reaction stage even at temperature of 140 °C (Fig. S25). Long-chain alkenes are subsequently cyclized into cycloalkanes. Hexene is cyclized into cyclohexane (C1) or methyl-cyclopentane (C2) with the free energy barriers of 62 and 69 kJ/mol, whereas heptene cyclizations to methyl-cyclohexane (C3) and ethyl-cyclopentane (C4) surmount free energy barriers of 76 and 67 kJ/mol, respectively. The similar free energy barriers of the above cyclization reactions suggest that formations of (alkyl)cyclopentane and (alkyl)cyclohexane are competitive [65,66], which is substantiated by the simultaneous detection of 5-membered and 6-membered ring hydrocarbons on MH-ZSM-5 in propene conversion experiments (Fig. 7(a)). Further conversions of cycloalkanes into cycloalkenes and aromatics can be achieved through dehydrogenation or hydrogen transfer reactions. By hydrogen transfer reactions, cyclohexane is transformed into cyclohexene (HT1), and further into cyclohexadiene (HT2) with free energy barriers of 108 and 118 kJ/mol respectively (Fig. 7(a)). Conversion of methyl-cyclohexane into methyl-cyclohexene (HT6) climbs a slightly higher free energy barrier of 123 kJ/mol, but subsequently into methyl-cyclohexadiene (HT7) demands a lower free energy barrier of 95 kJ/mol. By the same reaction pathway, the free energy barriers for the formations of methyl-cyclopentene (HT4) and methyl-cyclopentadiene (HT5) from methyl-cyclopentane are 114 and 120 kJ/mol, whereas for the generations of ethyl-cyclopentene (HT9) and -cyclopentadiene (HT10) from ethyl-cyclopentane are 124 and 91 kJ/mol, respectively. These alkyl-cyclopentenes and -cyclopentadienes can be expanded into 6-membered ring hydrocarbons [67,68]. The free energy barriers for the ring expansions of methyl-cyclopentene and methyl-cyclopentadiene into cyclohexene (RE1 + RE1*) and cyclohexadiene (RE2 + RE2*) are similar, being 173 and 185 kJ/mol respectively. In comparison, the ring expansions of ethyl-cyclopentene and -cyclopentadiene into methyl-cyclohexene (RE3 + RE3*) and methyl-cyclohexadiene (RE4 + RE4*) are much easier, as the free energy barriers decrease to 99 and 133 kJ/mol respectively. The above calculation results suggest that (alkyl)cyclopentane is firstly converted into (alkyl)cyclopentene, and then, to (alkyl)cyclopentadiene, which is followed by the ring-expansion to (alkyl)cyclohexadiene. On H-ZSM-5, the pathway for conversions of (alkyl)cycloalkanes into (alkyl)cycloalkenes, and further into (alkyl)aromatics is dominated by the hydrogen transfer reaction, as direct dehydrogenations show far higher energy barriers (e.g. methyl cyclohexane, 123 kJ/mol (HT6) vs. 165 kJ/mol (DH8*), Fig. 7(a) and Fig. S26). In contrast, on Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.3 with [GaH]2+ species located at ion-exchange sites, the dehydrogenation was significantly promoted. The free energy barriers for the dehydrogenation of methyl-cyclopentane into methyl-cyclopentene (DH6), and subsequently into methyl-cyclopentadiene (DH7) on, e.g. Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.3, are 91 and 72 kJ/mol. The dehydrogenation of ethyl-cyclopentane into ethyl-cyclopentene (DH11) and ethyl-cyclopentadiene (DH12) are more facile, as the free energy barriers are lowered to 80 and 61 kJ/mol respectively. In addition, cyclohexane is easily dehydrogenated into cyclohexene (DH3), cyclohexadiene (DH4), and further into benzene (DH5) with free energy barriers of 118, 92 and 81 kJ/mol, respectively (Fig. 7(b)). The dehydrogenations of methyl-cyclohexane into methyl-cyclohexene (DH8), methyl-cyclohexadiene (DH9), and further into toluene (DH10) are more rapid due to their lower free energy barriers (102, 39 and 60 kJ/mol, respectively). Notably, the free energy barriers for sequential dehydrogenation of (alkyl)cyclo-pentanes and (alkyl)cyclo-hexanes into aromatics on [GaH]2+ species are lower than those of the corresponding hydrogen transfer reactions on Brønsted acid sites (Fig. 7(a)). Consequently, significantly larger amounts of aromatics were produced on the Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.3 than on the MH-ZSM-5 at the same conditions in propane aromatization (Fig. 8 ). Fig. 8 shows the formation and evolution of various reaction intermediates in propane aromatization, as detected by temperature-dependent propene conversion probe experiments. Once propene was introduced into the reactor, it was quickly oligomerized into C6 and C7 alkenes, as indicated by the peaks at retention time around 6 and 8 min respectively (Fig. 8(a)), on MH-ZSM-5 at a temperature as low as 140 °C. The peak intensities or the amounts of C6 and C7 alkenes exhibit a volcanic relationship with the reaction temperature with maximum at ~230 °C. Regardless of this, the amounts of cyclic hydrocarbon intermediates, including cyclohexane, cyclohexene, cyclohexadiene, methylcyclopentene, methyl cyclopentadiene, methylcyclohexane, dimethylcyclopentane, dimethylcyclopentene, methylcyclohexene and methylcyclohexadiene etc. were quickly increased with elevating reaction temperature up to ca. 310–340 °C, and then decreased due to further evolution into aromatic species. The ethyl-cyclopentene and -cyclopentadiene were nearly undetectable due to lower free energy barriers of their ring expansions (RE3 and RE4), as supported by detecting methyl-cyclopentenyl compounds but difficultly differentiating ethyl-cyclopentenyl species in the temperature-dependent propene conversion probe experiments (Fig. 8). Aromatics such as benzene and toluene were observed at around 390 and 310 °C respectively, and their amounts increased with the reaction temperature. Similar results were obtained on Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.3 (Fig. 8(b)), indicating that introduction of [GaH]2+ in zeolites does not alter the reaction pathway of propane aromatization. Nevertheless, the onset temperature for the formation of benzene and toluene was decreased from 390 and 310 °C on MH-ZSM-5 to 340 and 290 °C on Ga-MH-ZSM-5, respectively. This shows that ion exchange of certain amounts of H+ with [GaH]2+ ions can effectively enhance the cyclo-alkane/alkene dehydrogenation to aromatics, which is in line with the DFT calculation results (Fig. 7). The reaction mechanism of propane aromatization was further investigated by combining temperature-programmed surface reaction of propane (propane-TPSR) with advanced PTR-TOF-MS. The peaks associated with cyclic hydrocarbon intermediates, e.g. methyl-cyclopentene, methyl-cyclopentadiene, cyclohexene, methyl-cyclohexene and methyl-cyclohexadiene, were clearly visible at 150–350 °C in the PTR-TOF-MS chromatogram obtained on MH-ZSM-5 (Figs. 9(a) and (b) ). These peaks were gradually attenuated, while those of benzene and toluene were enhanced with the reaction temperature (Fig. 9(c)). Notably, the peaks characteristic of cyclopentenyl and cyclohexenyl intermediates generated on Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.3 are very weak at 200–400 °C in PTR-TOF-MS (Figs. 9(d) and (e)). This is due to their facile conversion into aromatics, as supported by easier formation of benzene and toluene on Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.3 than on MH-ZSM-5 (Fig. 9(f) and Fig. S27). When the reaction temperature was increased to 450 °C, significantly more cyclic hydrocarbons and aromatic products were produced on Ga-MH-ZSM-5, as [GaH]2+ species shows high activity for propane dehydrogenation to propene. Table S12 displays the generated aromatics, H2, and for comparison, theoretically produced H2 yields on Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.41 at different reaction temperatures. In addition, the dehydrogenation degrees were estimated. If propane is converted into aromatics through dehydrogenation on [GaH]2+ and [GaH2]+ species, formation of one mole of aromatics would theoretically produce five moles of H2, as shown in the following reactions: (3) 2C3H8 → C6H6 + 5H2 (4) 3C3H8 → C7H8 + 5H2 + C2H6 (5) 3C3H8 → C8H10 + 5H2 + CH4 However, it is inevitable that a certain amount of aromatics is produced through hydrogen transfer reaction. Table S12 shows that ~95% of aromatics are generated at 580 °C via direct dehydrogenation, and ~5% of aromatics are generated through hydrogen transfer reactions. This is in agreement with the kinetic study and DFT calculation results that Ga species catalyze dehydrogenations of both propane and cyclic hydrocarbon intermediates (Fig. 7(b)). This gives another piece of evidence for [GaH]2+ species to show much higher catalytic activity than Brønsted acid sites for alkane dehydrogenation, and accounts well for the remarkably higher aromatics selectivity of Ga-MH-ZSM-5-x than of MH-ZSM-5. 4 Conclusions Single Ga3+ species has been located at the ion-exchanged sites of mesoporous hollow-structured ZSM-5. The obtained material shows unprecedentedly high catalytic activity, product selectivity and catalytic stability in light alkane aromatization. XANES, EXAFS, FT-IR, 71Ga MAS NMR, PTR-TOF-MS, kinetics study and DFT computation results reveal that Ga species and Brønsted acid sites collaboratively catalyze the reaction; Ga species dehydrogenate propane and cyclic hydrocarbon intermediates to propene and aromatics respectively, while Brønsted acid sites oligomerize propene to long-chain alkenes and further cyclize to cycloalkanes despite that they also promote the hydrogen transfer reactions of alkanes/alkenes with alkenes. [Ga(OH)]2+ ions are predominant species at Ga loading ≤ 0.3 wt%, while [Ga(OH)2]+ species are also formed when Ga content is between 0.3 wt% and 0.47 wt%. Further elevation of Ga loading leads to formation of GaO x clusters, and their amount increases with increasing Ga loading. After H2 treatment, all the [Ga(OH)]2+ and [Ga(OH)2]+ species are transformed into [GaH]2+ and [GaH2]+ ions respectively. [GaH]2+ species exhibits propane dehydrogenation activity as high as 20 and 300 times of those of [GaH2]+ and Brønsted acid site respectively. Thus, the catalytic activity is highly dependent on the amount of [GaH]2+ species. Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.41 shows propane conversion of 97.4%–88.5% and aromatics selectivity of 78.2 wt%–73.6 wt% at 580 °C within 20 h. The BTX accounts for ca. 88% of the generated aromatics. In particular, it can be reused with regeneration, as evidenced by the aromatics selectivity and the catalytic lifetime maintained at ca. 70 wt% and 80 h respectively within four repeated runs. This catalyst also shows an ethane conversion of ≈ 25% and an aromatics selectivity of ≈ 73.5 wt%, along with ≈ 96% of aromatics being BTX, at 600 °C, 1 atm and WHSV of 0.8 h–1 within at least 28 h in ethane aromatization. This work not only provides an outstanding light alkanes aromatization catalyst, but also clearly illustrates the catalytic roles of Brønsted acid sites and Ga species. In particular, the intrinsic catalytic activity of various Ga species was quantitatively determined. Therefore, it will be significantly beneficial to design of a high-performance Ga-based catalyst for aromatization, and even dehydrogenation of light alkanes, alkenes and naphtha. coredata.dc:description: Aromatization of light alkanes is a value-added process in both petrochemical and coal chemical industries. Here, single [Ga(OH)]2+ ion-exchanged mesoporous hollow-structured ZSM-5 (Ga-MH-ZSM-5) material was prepared, and it shows unprecedented catalytic performance in light alkane aromatization, considering activity, product selectivity and catalytic stability. The average aromatics yields in ethane aromatization at 600 °C and WHSV of 0.8 h–1 within 28 h and in propane aromatization at 580 °C and WHSV of 1.1 h–1 within 20 h reach ~18.4% and ~70.8% with benzene, toluene and xylenes (BTX) accounting for ~96% and ~88% of aromatics, respectively. Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.41 gave a TON for formation of aromatics (TONaromatics) from propane as high as 57479, whereas the reported catalysts maximally show a TONaromatics of 5514. This also holds true for ethane aromatization; the TONaromatics obtained on Ga-MH-ZSM-5-0.41 was ≥ 3845 in contrast to ≤ 392 on reported non-noble metal catalysts. The catalytic activity of Ga-MH-ZSM-5 highly depends on Ga species structures. [Ga(OH)]2+ ions are predominant species at Ga loading ≤ 0.3 wt%, while more [Ga(OH)2]+ and GaO x oligomers are formed with increasing Ga content. Upon reduction with H2, [Ga(OH)]2+ and [Ga(OH)2]+ are transformed into [GaH]2+ and [GaH2]+ species, which show a propane dehydrogenation rate of 300 and 15 times of that of Brønsted acid sites respectively. The light alkanes are mainly dehydrogenated into light olefins on [GaH]2+ species, and then, oligomerized and cyclized into (alkyl)cycloalkanes on H+ sites, which is followed by possible ring expansion on H+ and sequential dehydrogenations into aromatics primarily on [GaH]2+.
